Article.Abstract: Cytotoxic T (Tc)-cell responses against influenza virus infection in BALB/c (H-2d) mice are dominated by Tc clones reactive to the viral nucleoprotein (NP). Here, we report investigations using recombinant vaccinia viruses (VV) encoding major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I H-2Kd molecules differing by a single amino acid from glutamine (wild-type, Kdw) to histidine (mutant, Kdm) at position 114 located in the floor of the peptide-binding groove. Influenza-infected target cells expressing Kdw were strongly lysed by Kd-restricted Tc cells against A/WSN influenza virus or the immunodominant peptide of viral NP (NPP147-155), whereas infected Kdm-expressing targets gave little or no lysis, respectively, thus showing the immunodominance of NPP147-155. Kdm-expressing target cells saturated with synthetic NPP147-155 (10-5 M) were lysed similarly to Kdw-expressing targets by NPP147-155-specific Tc cells. Thus the defect in influenza-infected Kdm-expressing targets was quantitative; insufficient Kdm-peptide complexes were expressed. Tc-cell responses against four other viruses or alloantigens showed no effect of Kdm. When peptide transport-defective cells were infected with VV-Kdw or VV-Kdm and co-infected with a recombinant VV encoding an endoplasmic reticulum-targeted viral peptide, two influenza haemaglutinin peptides caused higher expression of Kdw than NPP147-155 indicating their higher affinity for Kdw. These results are inconsistent with the hypothesis that immunodominance in the anti-influenza response reflects high affinity of the immunodominant peptide, but are consistent with skewing of the Tc-cell receptor repertoire.
Article.ArticleTitle: High peptide affinity for MHC class I does not correlate with immunodominance.
Article.Affiliations: Division of Immunology and Cell Biology, John Curtin School of Medical Research, Australian National University, Canberra, A.C.T. 2601, Australia.
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Animals; Antigen Presentation; H-2 Antigens(genetics; immunology; metabolism); Immunodominant Epitopes; Influenza A virus(genetics; immunology); Isoantigens; Mice; Mice, Inbred BALB C; Mice, Inbred C3H; Mice, Inbred C57BL; Mutation; Nucleoproteins(immunology; metabolism); Orthomyxoviridae Infections(immunology); Peptide Fragments(immunology; metabolism); Protein Binding; Recombinant Proteins(immunology); T-Lymphocytes, Cytotoxic(immunology); Vaccinia virus(genetics)

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: The generation of the anti-eptiope cell line was previously described.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Wild type Kd-expressing target cells infected Flu are efficiently lysed by NP147-155 specific T cells, while mutant Kd (where aa141, located at the floor of the peptide binding groove, is changed from Q to H)-expressing cells are not recognized. The same results are seen when target cells are infected with recombinant vaccinia enconding the Flu nucleoprotein. The presentation of epitope in mutant Kb-peptide loaded cells is not affected at high concentrations.

Wild type Kd expressing cells are abl[e to bind this immunodominant epitope, while mutant Kd (where aa141, located at the floor of the peptide binding groove, is changed from Q to H) molecules fail to efficiently present epitope, although other source species peptides are efficiently presented. Since mutant Kd-expressing cells infected with Flu are not lysed by Flu-specific T-cells, the presentation of those other peptides from Flu over the level of immunodominant epitope NP147-155 is not sufficient to change the immunodominance pattern, implying that MHC affinity is not a determinant of immunodominance.
